data.response: The average cost of a regular IVF cycle at our clinic is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs, depending on the treatment required. This includes all medical procedures and some additional costs for medications and freezing embryos.

source.context:
What is the Cost for IVF?
A complete IVF cycle at our clinic costs about Rs 3,00,000 - and this is all-inclusive for all medical procedures. Medicines would cost about Rs  145000 more.

 Included services in our IVF cost:

    Ovarian stimulation monitoring

    Anesthesia for egg retrieval

    Egg retrieval procedure

    Fertilization and culture of the eggs

   All physician, IVF lab, and facility fees associated with in vitro fertilization

There is NO extra cost for doing ICSI or a blastocyst transfer !

Excluded services - not included in our IVF costs:

    Pre-IVF screening tests 

   Blood tests ( such as E2 levels)

    Embryo or sperm freezing or storage - these are optional services

The cost for freezing and storing embryos is Rs 70000 per year

The cost for thawing and transferring them is Rs 70000

We do NOT charge for followup consultations; or for reviewing test results.

https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf
The total cost to have a baby ( your final goal !)  will depend upon the number of cycles required to achieve success.

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of IVF can vary depending on several factors, including the location of the clinic, the specific treatments and procedures involved, any additional services or medications required, and the individual needs of the patient. It's best to consult with your chosen clinic for a detailed breakdown of costs. In our clinic, the charges vary from Rs 2 lakhs to 3 lakhs per cycle for the medical treatment expenses. Injections and additional procedures, such as embryo freezing, cost extra. Please email us at drmalpani@drmalpani.com so we can share the exact pricing structure with you

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of an IVF procedure can vary depending on various factors. At Dr. Malpani's IVF clinic, the average cost of a regular IVF cycle is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs. This includes clinical fees, consultation, ultrasound monitoring, medication costs, blood tests, pre-IVF tests, operation theater costs, vaginal egg collection, embryo transfer, cyst aspiration, PESA/TESE (surgical sperm retrieval), IVF laboratory costs (ICSI), embryo freezing and thawing, and embryo storage. Please note that this is an all-inclusive package cost and may vary based on individual requirements. [Read More](https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf-treatment-in-india)

What is the Cost for IVF?
The average cost of a regular IVF cycle with a fresh blastocyst transfer at Malpani Infertility Clinic is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs (depending on the cost of injections and if you have embryos to freeze). We don't charge extra for doing ICSI and culturing to blastocyst stage For a specific quotation based on your individual needs, please email [info@drmalpani.com](mailto:info@drmalpani.com) and they will be happy to assist you. [Read More](https://www.drmalpani.com/knowledge-center/articles/cost-of-ivf-old)

What is the Cost for IVF?
The cost of IVF at Dr. Malpani's clinic is approximately Rs 2 to 4 lakhs, depending on the specific treatment required and if you have embryos to freeze. This includes all medical procedures, scans, egg pickup, and embryo culture to Day 5 (blastocyst). Additional costs include consultation fees and pre-IVF tests. Embryo freezing and storage are extra. Medication costs can vary but are typically around Rs 100000 more for one complete cycle.

Can you provide a general estimate of the cost range for IVF at your clinic?
The general cost for a complete IVF cycle at our clinic is between Rs 3 lakhs - Rs 5 lakhs Additional costs may include consultation fees (US $20, or around Rs. 1500) and the cost of pre-IVF tests and medications (approximately US $1000, or around Rs. 85,000).

Can you provide a detailed breakdown? The general cost for a complete IVF cycle at our clinic is between Rs 3 lakhs - Rs 5 lakhs. Additional costs may include consultation fees (Rs. 3000) and the cost of pre-IVF tests and medications (approximately around Rs. 35,000). data.response: Treatment for pus cells in semen is not necessary unless there is an actual infection present. Often, the presence of a few pus cells on a semen analysis report could be misinterpreted as an infection when they are actually immature sperm precursors. It's important to consult with a specialist who can accurately interpret the results before starting any treatment.

source.context: Pus cells in the semen - and how to make sense of the report The bottom line is if your semen report does show a few pus cells, please don't panic ! Please repeat it again, and ask the lab to do the special stains needed to check if these are actually WBCs. Otherwise, your wife will keep on getting older and losing her fertility, while you waste time because of a poor quality laboratory, or a poorly informed gynecologist .

Pus cells in the semen - and how to make sense of the report One of the common findings in a semen analysis report is the presence of a few pus cells per high power field ( pus cells/ hpf). The technical word for this is called pyospermia or leucocytospermia. Pus cells are WBCs - white blood cells, and less than 5 pus cells / hpf is considered to be normal, but this finding is often highlighted in red as being abnormal, and this often causes both the doctor as well as the patient to worry.The WHO Manual states that less than 1 million WBC per ml is normal, but the majority of labs never bother to measure the actual concentration of the WBCs - the technician simply eyeballs the sample and estimate this in terms of rounds cells seen in each visual field when scanning the samples through the microscope. Patients are worried that these pus cells suggest they are suffering from an occult infection - perhaps a sexually transmitted disease ( STD) which they knew they had acquired in the past, and they are worried that they can transmit this to their wife.They are also worried that this hidden infection can kill their sperm, or reduce their ability to fertilise the eggs.Doctors are also happy to "treat" this abnormality by putting the man on antibiotics, because these are so easy to prescribe, and because this seems to be a logical thing to do. They hope these antibiotics will kill the bugs causing the infection, and this will boost the man's fertility. The reason this is flawed logic is because the "pus cells" seen on a semen analysis report when checked through the microscope are simply round cells, which are misinterpreted as being pus cells .When examining the semen under the microscope, it's very easy to identify sperm because they have a tail and are moving rapidly. However, seminal fluid also contains many other cells, including the epithelial cells which line the male reproductive tract, as well as sperm precursor cells. Most laboratory technicians will report every round cell they see as a pus cell or a WBC , but most of these are actually immature sperm precursors, called spermatocytes or spermatogonia , which look exactly the same. However, most labs don't have the special stains needed to identify whether this round cell is a WBC or not , which is why they will report all the round cells as pus cells !The doctor then promptly prescribes antibiotics, but this is a complete waste, because there was no infection in the first place, and antibiotics will not cause the sperm precursor cells to go away !Patients end up wasting a lot of time and money on taking antibiotics . Some doctors will also send the semen sample to the microbiology lab to try to culture the microbe causing the purported infection.

data.response: Treatment for pus cells in semen is not necessary unless there is an actual infection present. Often, the presence of a few pus cells on a semen analysis report could be misinterpreted as an infection when they are actually immature sperm precursors. It's important to consult with a specialist who can accurately interpret the results before starting any treatment.

Pus cells are WBCs - white blood cells, and less than 5 pus cells / hpf is considered to be normal, but this finding is often highlighted in red as being abnormal, and this often causes both the doctor as well as the patient to worry.The WHO Manual states that less than 1 million WBC per ml is normal, but the majority of labs never bother to measure the actual concentration of the WBCs - the technician simply eyeballs the sample and estimate this in terms of rounds cells seen in each visual field when scanning the samples through the microscope. They hope these antibiotics will kill the bugs causing the infection, and this will boost the man's fertility. The reason this is flawed logic is because the "pus cells" seen on a semen analysis report when checked through the microscope are simply round cells, which are misinterpreted as being pus cells .When examining the semen under the microscope, it's very easy to identify sperm because they have a tail and are moving rapidly. However, seminal fluid also contains many other cells, including the epithelial cells which line the male reproductive tract, as well as sperm precursor cells. Most laboratory technicians will report every round cell they see as a pus cell or a WBC , but most of these are actually immature sperm precursors, called spermatocytes or spermatogonia , which look exactly the same. However, most labs don't have the special stains needed to identify whether this round cell is a WBC or not , which is why they will report all the round cells as pus cells !The doctor then promptly prescribes antibiotics, but this is a complete waste, because there was no infection in the first place, and antibiotics will not cause the sperm precursor cells to go away !Patients end up wasting a lot of time and money on taking antibiotics . data.response: Yes, I am interested in early-stage startups with paying customers and a pre-money valuation of about Rs 10-50 crores.

source.context:
What type of startups are you interested in?
I am interested in early-stage startups with paying customers and a pre-money valuation of about Rs 10-50  crores. [Read More](https://www.indianangel.in/i-would-like-entrepreneurs-to-suggest-names-of-startups-i/7145/)

Are we the right investors for you? Finally, our sweet spot is the angel stage. We like to come in early and work closely with entrepreneurs who are building their ventures. Our ticket size is anywhere between Rs 50 lacs to 150 lacs depending on the age, maturity of business model, and our comfort level with the entrepreneurs. At the same time, we also provide the entrepreneur with an unwavering support in their quest to grow their venture, and at times also participate in bridge and follow on rounds to show solidarity. Because we like to come in early and bet on yet unproven business models untested at scale, we prefer to have sizeable skin in the game for it to make it worth our while. While we do not like to negotiate with entrepreneurs on the valuation of their ventures and want them to propose the valuation they are comfortable with, we prefer pre-money valuations between Rs 5 cr to 15 cr above which it has to be either an extremely superior business model or very strong credibility of the entrepreneur for us to consider our participation. And until it is time for the startups to learn from professional venture capitalists, we will be happy to handhold them in all walks of life.We are always looking for exciting new startups to invest in, and bright entrepreneurs to learn from. If your startup fits our investment thesis as mentioned above, we would love to hear from you.

When I first started investing in startups, we would take ... When I first started investing in startups, we would take pride in saying Yes quickly, and No quickly as well. After 4 years, we are no longer willing to say yes quickly, and spend a  lot more time on due-diligence! We have  realised the hard way that being able to pick the right founders makes a big difference to the outcome of the startups we fund, and that it's hard to judge a founder's character without having multiple interactions over time with them ,

Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope ... Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope that they will be able to find the next unicorn . Startups which have been plodding along for many years find it very hard to attract investors , because they haven't been able to show exponential growth during their journey .  However, these are actually a better bet for angel investors , because they are proven to be antifragile ! The founders have learned a lot about their domain , and have a reputation to protect. They have existing customers , and can tap into their network to grow, once they are funded.  Also, the competition for investing in these start-ups is much less , which means the pre money valuation is also much more reasonable ! ,

The MVP (minimum viable product) myth A \u201cminimum viable product\u201d - MVP - is also a highly abstract concept in the mind of the entrepreneur.     After all, viability can only be judged by the user!      And let\u2019s admit it: what is minimally viable depends largely on your audience\u2019s tolerance for lack of quality.    From the book, Innovating: A Doer's Manifesto for Starting from a Hunch, Prototyping Problems, Scaling Up, and Learning to Be Productively Wrong by Luis Perez-Breva

With the last questions, you are not looking for design advice; test subjects aren\u2019t good at that.  Instead, you are probing for unmet needs.  So, if they say something\u2019s missing, your response should be, \u201cOkay, why would you want that? \u201d A question to avoid is \u201cWould you use this? \u201d As with interview and survey questions, the answer from someone eager to please will too often be \u201cyes. \u201d

MVP Testing.  Prototyping and prototype testing should proceed in iterative loops until a dominant design emerges.  Based on test feedback, designers should reject some prototypes and refine others, producing higher-fidelity versions.  Once they converge on a single, favored solution, it\u2019s time for minimum viable product testing. 

An MVP is a prototype\u2014a facsimile of the future product.  What distinguishes an MVP from other prototypes is how it is tested.  Rather than sitting across a table, getting verbal feedback from a reviewer, you put a prototype that seems like a real product in the hands of real customers in a real-world context.  The goal is to quickly but rigorously test assumptions about the demand for your solution\u2014and gain what Eric Ries calls \u201cvalidated learning\u201d\u2014with as little wasted effort as possible.  A good MVP should embody the lowest fidelity possible to get reliable feedback because lower fidelity implies less wasted effort.  Put another way, an MVP should provide no more \u201clooks like\u201d polish and \u201cworks like\u201d functionality than is strictly necessary to conduct a test.  Functionality comes in two flavors.  Front-end functionality encompasses everything directly experienced by customers; for Wings it was daters\u2019 profiles, daily matches, messaging, search, etc.  Back-end functionality is invisible to the customer but integral to serving them.  For Wings, this would include the life-stream connectors, the matching algorithm, the servers, etc. 

MVPs come in four basic types, depending on whether they constrain front-end functionality, back-end functionality, or both:

Constrained Front-End Functionality.  These MVPs omit peripheral product features and focus only on the solution\u2019s core front-end features.  If customers don\u2019t perceive the core features to be valuable, there\u2019s no point in building the rest. 

Constrained Back-End Functionality.  MVPs can rely on makeshift, temporary methods to perform functions that are not visible to the customer\u2014for example, having humans analyze digital data to suggest matches instead of relying on software algorithms.  Again, there\u2019s no point in investing in automation until demand is validated.

data.response: Determining pre-money valuation involves a mix of art and science. Typically, it's based on the market value of similar companies, the amount you plan to raise (which can influence valuation), and negotiations with potential investors.

source.context: An entrepreneur emailed me this query. Is there a way ... An entrepreneur emailed me this query. Is there a way to value a company with no sales  as yet? I have been struggling to get the right answer to this. There is no formula for determining a value for a pre-revenue company. Value = what someone is willing to pay for it.  Beauty lies in the eye of the beholder!  ,
upon a fully diluted pre-money valuation of $[INSERT PRE\u00ad MONEY VALUATION]. (continued )

beta?  MBA-type readers can discount-cashflow  themselves to pieces, but a startup\u2019s value is simply not determined by evaluating its assets.  So if someone\u2019s going to invest in you, how much of the company do they get?  To figure  this out, you need to know your premoney valuation\u2014how much your company is worth.  Yes, the thing I just told you that you can\u2019t calculate.  Here\u2019s how it really happens.  First, startups are valued by the market.  This is often the dominant factor.  What are similar companies getting as premoney valu-

of valuations and funding amounts set everyone up for success down the line, with founders who still have enough stock to become wealthy and investors who get the returns they need for their funds.  And it turns out that all these numbers are strongly driven by the amount raised.  Investors will generally buy 20%\u201335% of the company in the investment round, so the premoney valuation tends to be a 3\u20135x factor of the amount raised.  That doesn\u2019t seem to make much sense (why is your company worth more if you raise more? ), but this approach does tend to correctly predict premoney valua-

210  ACQUIRING THE TREASURE It\u2019s time to revisit the all-important subject of valuation. In my first financing, we had a pre-money valuation of $5 million for our startup, Brainstorm. Since my cofounder and I owned most of the company,  I thought that meant we were multimillionaires, at least on paper. As we saw in Startup Model #5: The Four Quadrants of Hiring this was a result of not understanding what went into a valuation. Here is another misconception of entrepreneurs who want to sell stock,

Securities Offered   Most of the investment would be of preferred shares, as opposed to common shares (yours).  The preferences of the preferred shares are usually in case of a liquidation event and special rights, as will be described later in the table.      Company Valuation   This is the main deal, together with the amount that constitutes the transaction (\u201cHow much for how much? \u201d).  Valuation defines how much what was built so far is worth.  There is no methodological way to define it, so most likely it will be negotiated based on your alternatives.  It is defined as pre-money valuation, which is the value of what was created so far, and together with the investment amount, that forms the post-money valuation\u2014the value of the company once the round is finalized.  There will be an immediate derivative of this valuation, which is PPS (Price Per Share) and number of shares in the company (prior to the round).    Mathematically, this is: pre-money valuation = PPS \u00d7 number of shares prior to the round.  And then the company issues new shares to the investors at the same PPS in a total amount of the investment amount.    One note: It is important to realize that while ISO/ESOP is critical to attract and retain employees, it is mostly used by the investor as a way to lower valuation.  ISO/ESOP allocation requires issuing more shares, a new share per option, essentially increasing the number of shares and therefore lowering the PPS.  So, a $10 million pre-money valuation with 10 percent ISO/ESOP is actually less than $9 million.  It is common practice that ISO/ESOP allocation comes from current shareholders and not new ones.  To have better negotiation leverage you will need another competitive offer.      Pre-emptive Rights; Right of First Refusal; Co-Sale   Pre-emptive rights\u2014The investor will have the right to participate in the next round to maintain its holding; so, for example, an investor with 10 percent of the company that participates in the next round can maintain its 10 percent position.  While it may seem fine that all they want is to increase their position, it may discourage the next investor.  Or, even worse, the next investor may ask for similar terms!    Right of first refusal\u2014The investor has the right to invest under the same terms as a new investor.

Before going to sleep, review your day for additional items to record in your evidence log.  Actively try to verify and thereby strengthen your new belief by testing its rules in a specific arena.  Select a low-  risk arena at first.  Perhaps you might test the rules just with a supportive friend, or just in the morning, or just at the coffee shop.

This is okay.  You can confirm that your new rules are valid with an evidence log, in which you record interactions, events, conversations\u2014 anything that will support your new rules and core beliefs.  This will strengthen your new core beliefs.  Whenever situations arise that support your new rule, record what happened and what it means.  Here are some examples from Bud\u2019s evidence log: What  happened:  I played  a trivia  game  at a party, and although I didn\u2019t win, I answered as many questions as Sam and Cindy.  What  it means:  I can hold my own in games  that require  thinking.

Explore the path back through time until you come to the place where you lived when you were four, five, or six, before you entered the first grade.  Pick a time when you were frightened and unhappy.  Maybe you had a fight with your cousin, your father came home drunk, your mom got hysterical, you got lost at the county fair, or the bully at day care threatened or attacked you.  See your preschool self in that scene.  Watch without being seen.  How tall are you?  Are you skinny or plump?  What are you wearing?  Are there any favorite toys around?  What color are your eyes?

How do I contact for Counseling?  Two ways: 1) Login on our website and you will be connected with our expert psychologists right away!  2) You can also simply email us at [info@mindworksbuddy. com](mailto:info@mindworksbuddy. com)  You can also freely share what's bothering you here in the chat.  This will help our counsellors understand you better.

For	example,	Dan	was	a	very	busy	salesman	who	spent	almost	all	of	hiswaking	hours	on	the	job. Does it mean I am not normal if I am seeking counseling?  Seeking counselling does not mean that a person is abnormal.  It signifies that the person wants some effective ways to handle a problem, or resolve the problematic issues.

The	counseling	for	this	couple	took	the	form	of\u201creframing,\u201d	in	which	Laura	and	Fred	questioned	the	basis	for	their	negativeperspectives	and	selected	a	more	benign	explanation	to	account	for	each	other\u2019sactions	(Chapter	13).

Aim and mission Believing strongly in the significance of mental well-being as important as physical well-being, working passionately in the field of offline and online counseling and therapy for 30+ years, experiencing the painful aftereffects of COVID-19 on general public\u2019s mental health, seeing the current trends of online services as easy access to the common public Mind Works Bait is established with a vision of reaching out to people struggling with their mental health concerns.  It aims to desensitize the stigma attached to counseling and provide access to high-quality and evidence-based mental health services in an affordable manner.  Mind Works Bait, is an online buddy to help individuals and families overcome emotional, behavioral & social challenges and achieve wholistic well-being.

What happens in the first session?  In the first session, our counsellor will try to understand about why you are seeking their help.  And it's also important for you to see if you are comfortable with your therapist!  Getting to know each other is very important before we can actually start helping you resolve your issues.
